title: Deputy IGP: We will keep tabs on Selva Kumar’s whereabouts
text:
Sunday, 5 February 2017 Deputy IGP: We will keep tabs on Selva Kumar’s whereabouts 
PETALING JAYA: For convicted rapist Selva Kumar Subbiah, who is to be deported from Canada today, this will be one homecoming he is not looking forward to and has been trying to avoid. 
The 57-year-old will be met on arrival at the KL International Airport by a team of policemen who will record his statement on his crimes in Canada. 
Police have not disclosed the exact date and time that Selva will arrive in Malaysia, but Deputy Inspector-General of Police Tan Sri Noor Rashid Ibrahim said that the police will meet him once he is back in the country and will keep tabs on him. 
“We are aware of public concerns regarding his release and deportation as he has a bad record but we have to accept the fact that he has the right, as a citizen, to come back,” he told reporters after attending the graduation ceremony of cadet Inspectors at the Police Training Centre (Pulapol). 
Noor Rashid said the police would check on where he would live, his future plans and details about his conviction. 
Asked whether the police could get Selva to wear a tracking device so that they could keep track of his movements, Noor Rashid said: “We cannot. So far, he has served his sentence. 
“Now he is free as he has already been charged and served his sentence. 
“So he is coming back as a normal person.” 
Jailed for 24 years in a Canadian prison for sexually assaulting do­zens of women in Toronto, Selva Kumar, who is from Penang, has fought long and hard against his deportation. 
He has even gone to the extent of claiming that he would be a victim of discrimination in Malaysia because he is “Jewish” and tried to block a newspaper in Toronto from publishing his picture. 
He reportedly went to Canada as a student in 1980 and his visa was extended after he was sponsored by a spouse. 
However, it was reported that during a parole board meeting last week, he said he had a “structured release plan” for his freedom in Malaysia as well as “strong family support”. 
He was said to be from “an affluent family”. 
The Star reported a former neighbour of Selva Kumar as saying that he was from a family of educationists, his late father being a senior education officer with the Penang Education Department and his late brother was a teacher at a primary school in the state. 
The third of four siblings – he has two older brothers and a younger sister – Selva Kumar is a former Penang Free School boy. 
Another relative said the father died years ago and his mother “is very sickly and being taken care of by a sister”.
